title: Separation Anxiety at Bedtime
wrong_way: Stop crying, you're fine! I'm right in the next room. You're just trying to make me stay.
phrase_1: You're feeling so sad and scared when I leave. You want me to stay with you. Your heart feels lonely.
say_it_like_this_step1: Sit on the bed, hold their hand, or offer a hug. Use a very soft, slow, loving voice. Make full, warm eye contact. Take a deep breath yourself.
avoid_step1: Don't stand at the door. Don't sound annoyed or rushed. Don't dismiss their fear. Don't say 'You're being a baby'.
phrase_2: It's so hard to say goodnight, AND it's time for our bodies to rest. I'll be right here (in the next room). Would you like one 'big bear hug', or for me to sing your lullaby one more time?
say_it_like_this_step2: Maintain physical contact (hand on shoulder, etc.). Your voice should be a 'blanket' of calm. Offer two choices focused on *comfort* and *connection*.
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'Okay, I'll stay 10 more minutes' (this is negotiating and delays the inevitable). Don't say 'but'.
phrase_3: You are safe, and you are learning to sleep on your own. This is hard, and you are doing it. I am going to check on you in 5 minutes. You can hold your bear tight until I come back.
say_it_like_this_step3: Say it with confidence and love. Give a kiss. The '5-minute check-in' promise is crucial and *must* be kept. Give them a 'job' (hold the bear).
avoid_step3: Don't leave and *not* come back. You *must* return in 5 minutes to build trust. Don't sound like you're asking; it's a statement.
neurological_tip: Separation anxiety is a real limbic system response. Co-regulation (your calm presence) and a predictable promise (the check-in) calms the amygdala and builds neural trust that they are safe.
what_to_expect_1: You *must* do the 5-minute check-in, even if it's just poking your head in to say 'I'm here'.
what_to_expect_2: It may take 1-2 weeks for them to trust the 'check-in' and feel secure.
what_to_expect_3: They may still cry for the first few minutes, but the crying will de-escalate faster.

title: Nighttime Fears (Monsters)
wrong_way: There's no monster! You're just being silly. Go to sleep!
phrase_1: You're feeling really scared right now. That shadow looks like a monster, and your heart is beating fast. That's a terrible feeling.
say_it_like_this_step1: Sit on the bed *with* them. Offer a hug. Use a serious, empathetic voice. This is not a time to be playful. You must take the *fear* seriously (even if the *cause* isn't real).
avoid_step1: Don't laugh. Don't say 'Don't be silly'. Don't turn on the main light (that's overstimulating). Don't say 'Monsters aren't real' (this invalidates the feeling).
phrase_2: That's a big, scary feeling, AND you are safe in your room. Let's give your brain what it needs to feel safe. Do you want me to use the 'monster spray' (water w/ lavender), or should we check under the bed with the 'courage flashlight'?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *feeling*, then shift to *safety*. The choices must be about *tools* of comfort and security that validate the emotion.
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'Can you sleep in my bed?'. Hold the boundary of their room. Don't make the 'check' a big, noisy game (this can 'prove' there's something to check for).
phrase_3: Your job is to keep your room safe, and my job is to help. You are safe. Let's take three deep 'dragon breaths' together to tell your brain it's okay.
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them with *co-regulation* tools (breathing) and *coping* tools (spray). Reaffirm their safety.
avoid_step3: Don't say 'See? There's nothing here'. Say 'Great, the room is safe'.
neurological_tip: 'Name it to tame it': Naming the fear (heart beating fast) engages the left-brain prefrontal cortex, which helps modulate right-brain emotional reactivity. Offering a sensory tool (lavender spray) calms the nervous system.
what_to_expect_1: The fear is real to them. Your goal is to teach them how to *manage* the fear, not *debunk* the source.
what_to_expect_2: They may need this routine for several nights in a row.
what_to_expect_3: Be consistent. The validation of the feeling is the most important step.

title: Stalling (I'm Sad the Day Is Over)
wrong_way: You're just stalling. It's time for bed. Enough!
phrase_1: You're feeling sad that the day is over. You had so much fun today and you don't want it to end.
say_it_like_this_step1: Sit with them for the last book. Use a soft, nostalgic voice. Offer a hug.
avoid_step1: Don't accuse them of 'stalling'. Don't get frustrated. Don't rush the end of the routine.
phrase_2: It's sad when a fun day is done, AND our bodies need rest so we can have *another* fun day tomorrow. What was your *favorite* part of today?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the emotion (sadness). Connect it to the reality (rest). The 'choice' here is a *connection* question that helps them process the day.
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'one more story'. The routine boundary is firm.
phrase_3: Let's close our eyes and think about (the favorite part they said). You can hold that good feeling in your heart while you sleep. You are so good at enjoying our days.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers their *emotional regulation*. You are teaching them to transition from a 'big' feeling (sadness at the end) to a 'calm' feeling (gratitude for the memory).
avoid_step3: Don't rush this part. Give them 30 seconds of silence to 'hold the feeling'.
neurological_tip: Intense children feel 'endings' deeply. This script validates that 'transition-sadness' and reframes it as gratitude, helping the brain shift from 'emotional' to 'rest' mode.
what_to_expect_1: This can become a beloved part of your bedtime routine.
what_to_expect_2: They will feel heard and understood, which allows them to relax.
what_to_expect_3: This helps them practice gratitude, which is a regulatory skill.

title: Over-Tired Meltdown
wrong_way: You are overtired. Just go to sleep! Stop fighting it!
phrase_1: Your body is so tired it can't relax. You are sleepy and angry at the same time. That's a very frustrating feeling.
say_it_like_this_step1: Reduce all stimuli. Turn off the main light, leave only a dim lamp. Stop talking. Just sit or lie down next to them. Give rhythmic, firm pats on their back.
avoid_step1: Don't try to 'cheer them up'. Don't ask questions. Don't try to reason. Don't get angry. Your frustration will fuel theirs.
phrase_2: You're exhausted. I'm right here. Shhh. It's okay. AND I am going to stay here until your body relaxes. Do you want 'back pats' or just for me to hold your hand?
say_it_like_this_step2: Use minimal words. Just 'calm presence'. The choice is *sensory* and *minimal*.
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'a story' or 'music'. That's more stimulation. The goal is to *reduce* input.
phrase_3: You are safe. Your body knows how to sleep. I'm right here. Shhh.
say_it_like_this_step3: Repeat a calm, monotone phrase. Your goal is to be a 'calm blanket'. You are empowering them to 'surrender' to sleep by showing them it's safe to do so.
avoid_step3: Don't leave as soon as their eyes close. Wait 5 minutes. They are in a fragile neurological state.
neurological_tip: When they are overtired, their sympathetic nervous system (fight-or-flight) is in overdrive. They can't access their parasympathetic (rest-and-digest). Your calm presence acts as an external regulator, allowing their nervous system to 'piggyback' on yours.
what_to_expect_1: This is a 'meltdown', not a 'script'. It can take 20 minutes.
what_to_expect_2: Your calm is the most important tool. If you are stressed, it will not work.
what_to_expect_3: This is co-regulation in its purest form.

title: Meltdown After Turn-Off
wrong_way: Stop this! You knew it was time! This is a ridiculous reaction!
phrase_1: You are so, so sad and angry that screen time is over. Your feelings are gigantic right now. You wanted to keep watching so much.
say_it_like_this_step1: Stop everything. Sit on the floor near them. Don't say much. Just be present. Breathe deeply and visibly. Your job is to be the 'calm anchor'.
avoid_step1: Don't try to reason. Don't threaten ('You'll never use this again!'). Don't minimize ('It's just a game!'). Don't grab them to 'contain' them.
phrase_2: Your feelings are huge. I see you. It's really hard to stop. AND screen time is finished. I am going to sit right here with you *while* you feel this sadness.
say_it_like_this_step2: 100% validation of the feeling. 100% firm on the boundary. The key is 'I will sit with you *while* you feel'. You are not trying to *stop* the feeling.
avoid_step2: Don't say 'but'. Don't say 'If you stop crying, we can...'. That's a bribe.
phrase_3: You are safe. This big feeling will pass. Your body is angry, and that's okay. When you're ready, your body will calm down. Do you want a hug, or do you want space?
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers their *emotional regulation*. You are giving them permission to feel, and confidence that the feeling will pass. The 'hug or space' choice gives them sensory control.
avoid_step3: Don't force a hug. If they scream 'space!', move back a bit and say 'Okay, I'm right here'.
neurological_tip: Intense children have high limbic reactivity. The 'off' is a sharp dopamine drop, and their system 'crashes'. Your calm co-regulation is the only thing that can bring them back.
what_to_expect_1: This can take 10-15 minutes. It cannot be rushed.
what_to_expect_2: They are learning that they can survive gigantic feelings of disappointment.
what_to_expect_3: When they are calm (could be 30 mins later), say 'That was a huge feeling. You got through it. Let's go get some water.'

title: Overstimulated by Screen
wrong_way: Stop bouncing off the walls! You're being crazy! Go to your room and calm down!
phrase_1: Wow! Your body is full of 'buzzy' energy! The screen put a lot of 'electricity' in you!
say_it_like_this_step1: Use a fun, but calm, voice. Make eye contact. Act as a neutral observer of the 'energy'.
avoid_step1: Don't blame them. Don't call them 'crazy' or 'bad'. Don't isolate them (this can be scary for an intense child).
phrase_2: That's a lot of stimulation, AND now we need to help your body calm down. Let's do 'heavy work'. Do you want to push the wall as hard as you can for 10 seconds, or do 20 frog jumps?
say_it_like_this_step2: Name the feeling (stimulation). Give a *sensory solution*. 'Heavy work' (proprioception) is neurologically calming.
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'sit and read'. Their body *needs* to move. Don't offer 'run around the house' (this builds energy).
phrase_3: You are in charge of calming your body. Let's go, push that wall! Show me how strong you are! You are telling your body it's time to settle.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *sensory self-regulation*. You are giving them a tool that works.
avoid_step3: Don't do this as a punishment. Do it as a 'superhero game' to get control of your body.
neurological_tip: Screens (especially fast-paced games) over-charge the sympathetic nervous system. Proprioceptive input (heavy work) activates the parasympathetic nervous system, which is the neurological 'brake'.
what_to_expect_1: They will likely laugh and find it fun.
what_to_expect_2: This teaches them to identify the 'buzzy' feeling and know what to do about it.
what_to_expect_3: This is far more effective than a 'time out'.

title: Refusing to Turn Off (Anxiety)
wrong_way: It doesn't matter if you're not 'finished'! Time is up! Give it to me!
phrase_1: You're feeling so frustrated because you didn't get to 'finish' the level. You really wanted to do it perfectly.
say_it_like_this_step1: Get down to their level. Use a very empathetic voice. Name the *reason* behind the refusal (perfectionism/frustration).
avoid_step1: Don't grab the device. Don't say 'It's just a game'. Don't minimize how important this is *to them*.
phrase_2: I know how frustrating it is not to finish something, AND our agreed screen time is over. It's really hard to stop in the middle. Do you want to *tell* me what you were going to do next, or do you want to *draw* the ending you wanted?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *frustration*. Hold the *boundary*. Offer a choice that helps them *process* the 'unfinished' feeling.
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'just one more minute'. This teaches that 'not finishing' gets them more time.
phrase_3: You can explain the plan to me. This is hard, and you are handling a big disappointment. You are good at handling hard things.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers their *emotional resilience*. You are praising the *process* (handling disappointment), not the *outcome* (winning the game).
avoid_step3: Don't rush their explanation. Listen actively for one minute.
neurological_tip: 'Name it to tame it': By letting them talk or draw, you are moving the frustration from the emotional brain (limbic) to the thinking brain (prefrontal), which is calming.
what_to_expect_1: They will feel respected and heard.
what_to_expect_2: This reduces the chance of the frustration turning into a full-blown rage.
what_to_expect_3: This teaches them that process matters more than perfection.

title: Frightened by Content
wrong_way: What? That wasn't scary! That was a cartoon! Stop being silly.
phrase_1: Wow, that part was really scary *for you*. You weren't expecting that, and your body got a big shock.
say_it_like_this_step1: Turn off the screen immediately. Pull them in for a hug. Speak in a soft, protective voice.
avoid_step1: Don't say 'It was nothing'. Don't laugh. Don't force them to 'watch it again to see it's okay'. Don't shame them.
phrase_2: That was a big scare, AND now you are safe with me. Let's get that 'scary picture' out of your brain. Do you want to hold an ice cube (sensory shock), or should we take a deep breath and 'blow' the fear away?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *fear*. Affirm the *safety*. Offer a *sensory choice* to 'reboot' the system. A sensory shock (like ice or cold water) can break an anxious thought-loop.
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'watch something happy'. Their brain needs a *break*, not more stimulation.
phrase_3: You are safe. Your body had a 'scare' reaction, and now we are helping it feel safe again. You are good at telling your body it's safe.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *interoceptive awareness* (feeling what's inside) and *self-regulation*.
avoid_step3: Don't talk *about* the 'scary thing' more. Focus on 'safety', 'breathing', and 'now'.
neurological_tip: Intense (HSC) children process stimuli more deeply. What is 'mild' to one child can be genuinely 'terrifying' to them. The sensory 'shock' (ice) helps 'change the channel' from the amygdala loop.
what_to_expect_1: The ice cube works surprisingly well. Just holding it.
what_to_expect_2: They may be fearful of screens for a bit. This is normal.
what_to_expect_3: They learn they can be scared and then recover.

title: Sensory Aversion (Texture)
wrong_way: Just eat it! It's just noodles! You're not leaving the table until you try it.
phrase_1: I see. You touched that with your fork and the texture feels 'slimy' (or 'hard'/'mushy') *to you*. Your body is saying 'yuck'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Stay 100% neutral and calm. No disgusted face, no angry face. Just observe.
avoid_step1: Don't force the 'one bite rule'. Don't shame them. Don't say 'But you liked it last week'. Don't make a separate meal.
phrase_2: I understand that texture doesn't feel good to you today, AND this is what's for dinner. You do not have to eat it. You can eat your 'safe' food [e.g., the rice and bread].
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the sensory aversion 100%. Hold the boundary (not making another meal). Give *permission* not to eat, while pointing to the safe options.
avoid_step2: Don't say 'but'. Don't bargain. Don't beg.
phrase_3: You are in charge of your body and what goes in your mouth. You know what feels safe for you. You can just keep the 'learning food' on your plate to 'keep it company'.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *body autonomy*. For a sensory child, feeling 'forced' can cause real panic. By removing the pressure, you remove the battle. The 'keep it company' job is a food therapy technique (exposure without pressure).
avoid_step3: Sensory aversions are neurological, not behavioral. Their brain is interpreting the texture as 'danger'. Removing the pressure is the only way to eventually build safety.
neurological_tip: They will *not* eat the learning food tonight. The success is a peaceful meal.
what_to_expect_1: This takes *months* or *years*. The goal is repeated, no-pressure exposure.
what_to_expect_2: They learn that you respect their body's signals.
what_to_expect_3: Mealtime-Overwhelmed by Choice|Hygiene-Toothpaste 'Too Spicy'

title: Overwhelmed by Choice
wrong_way: There's nothing to cry about! It's just food! Just pick something!
phrase_1: Wow, looking at all that pasta feels like 'too much'. It's a very 'full' plate and your brain doesn't know where to start.
say_it_like_this_step1: Use a soft voice. Take their plate for a second.
avoid_step1: Don't get frustrated at their 'paralysis'. Don't say 'Are you hungry or not?'.
phrase_2: That's a lot of pasta, AND I can help. Do you want me to put just a *little* bit back on your plate, or do you want me to help you get the 'magic first bite'?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the 'overwhelm'. Offer a *scaffolding* choice. You're offering to help them *start*, which is the hardest part.
avoid_step2: Don't take the food away without asking. Don't just start feeding them (this removes autonomy).
phrase_3: You can do this. Let's get this first bite together. You're in charge.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *task initiation*. You are being their 'external prefrontal cortex', helping them overcome the emotional paralysis.
avoid_step3: Don't continue feeding them. Just the first bite to 'break the ice'.
neurological_tip: Intense children can be overwhelmed by visual stimuli (a too-full plate) or too many choices. This is analysis paralysis. Helping them with the 'First Step' is an executive function strategy.
what_to_expect_1: They will likely relax and start eating after the first bite.
what_to_expect_2: This stops them from escalating into a full meltdown over something 'simple'.
what_to_expect_3: You are co-regulating the start of the meal.

title: Too Distracted by Environment
wrong_way: Sit down! Stop looking around! Eat your food!
phrase_1: I notice the TV (or: the dog barking, the lights) is making it really hard for your brain to focus on food. It's very distracting.
say_it_like_this_step1: Get down to their level. Speak softly, right into their ear.
avoid_step1: Don't yell 'over' the distraction. Don't blame them for 'not listening'.
phrase_2: There's a lot going on, AND right now it's eating time. I need your help. Can you be the 'Focus Leader'? Can you show me how to 'focus on your plate' and block out the rest?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *distraction*. Hold the *boundary*. Offer a 'job' of *focus*. This is the opposite of 'don't be distracted'.
avoid_step2: Don't say 'If you don't eat, I'm turning off the TV' (do that *before* the meal). This script is for *unexpected* distractions.
phrase_3: Your brain is powerful. Show me how you can tell it to focus. I'll focus with you. Let's both focus on taking three bites.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *attention* (an executive function). You're making it a partnership 'game' instead of a 'command'.
avoid_step3: Don't expect this to last the whole meal. You may have to 'reset' the focus 2-3 times.
neurological_tip: Intense children are more susceptible to environmental stimuli (the 'S' for 'Sensitivity to Subtleties' in DOES). The distraction isn't willful. This script helps them practice 'filtering' stimuli.
what_to_expect_1: The ideal is to remove the distraction (turn off TV), but this isn't always possible (at a restaurant).
what_to_expect_2: This teaches them a real-world 'mindfulness' skill.
what_to_expect_3: They feel like a partner, not a problem.

title: Picky Eating (Emotional)
wrong_way: This is what you ate yesterday! Stop being difficult! Just eat it!
phrase_1: I know you *usually* like chicken, but today your body is saying 'no'. It feels like you just want 'safe' foods right now.
say_it_like_this_step1: Stay calm. Respect their 'no'. Remember, your job is to *offer*, theirs is to *decide*.
avoid_step1: Don't take it personally. Don't say 'But I made this just for you!'. Don't force them.
phrase_2: I understand, AND this is the meal. You do not have to eat the chicken. Remember you have (rice and carrots) on your plate. You are welcome to eat those.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the emotional 'no'. Hold the *boundary* (no other meal). Offer *permission* to eat only the safe parts.
avoid_step2: Don't make a big deal about it. Don't bargain 'two bites of chicken'.
phrase_3: You are in charge of your plate. You decide what goes in your mouth. You are a great listener to your body.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *body autonomy* and *intuition*. You are praising them for 'listening to their body', which is a healthy life skill.
avoid_step3: Don't praise them if they 'try it'. And don't critique them if they don't. Be neutral.
neurological_tip: Sometimes 'picky eating' is about emotional control, not the food. Intense children use 'safe' foods (usually carbs) to feel secure when they are emotionally overwhelmed. Respecting this removes the battle.
what_to_expect_1: They will eat only the rice and carrots. That is fine.
what_to_expect_2: They feel safe and respected at the table.
what_to_expect_3: This prevents food battles from becoming eating disorders. It's a long-term win.

title: Leaving Park (Emotional)
wrong_way: I warned you five minutes ago! We are leaving! Stop crying!
phrase_1: You are so, so sad to leave the park. You love this swing so much. You wish you could stay all day. It feels heart-breaking.
say_it_like_this_step1: Get down. Use a 'sad', empathetic voice. Match their tone. Offer a hug. Don't pull their arm.
avoid_step1: Don't say 'We'll come back tomorrow' (unless it's 100% true). Don't say 'You're fine'. Don't say 'It's not a big deal'.
phrase_2: It's really, really hard to leave, AND our time is up. Let's say 'goodbye' to the swings. Do you want to 'hug' the slide goodbye, or do you want to hold this 'special park rock' to take home?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *sadness* (heart-breaking). Hold the *boundary*. Offer a *closing ritual* choice. This gives their brain a 'bridge' for the transition.
avoid_step2: Don't offer '5 more minutes'. The transition *is* the problem.
phrase_3: You can carry that sad feeling all the way to the car. I will help you carry it. You are so good at feeling things big!
say_it_like_this_step3: This may sound strange, but you are *praising* the *intensity* of their feeling. You are empowering them to *be* intense, rather than shaming them for it.
avoid_step3: Don't try to 'fix' the sadness. Just *accompany* it to the car.
neurological_tip: 'Name it to tame it': By naming the emotion as 'heart-breaking sadness', you help their brain process it. The 'closing ritual' (hug slide) is an executive function tool that signals 'ending' to the brain.
what_to_expect_1: They will *still* cry. But it will be a 'connected' cry (with you), not a 'fighting' cry (against you).
what_to_expect_2: This is exhausting for the parent, but it's what works.
what_to_expect_3: They learn that their big feelings are welcome and safe.

title: Rushed Transition Meltdown
wrong_way: We are late! Stop crying and put your shoes on! You're making it worse!
phrase_1: I know, I'm rushing you and that makes you feel anxious and upset! You hate feeling rushed. It feels 'scrambled' in your brain.
say_it_like_this_step1: STOP. Take a breath. Get down. Apologize. 'I'm sorry, I'm rushing and that's stressing you out.'
avoid_step1: Don't blame the child for your own lack of time. Don't say 'It's your fault we're late'.
phrase_2: I hate this rushed feeling too, AND we *do* need to leave. I need your help. Can you be the 'Shoe Boss' or the 'Door Boss'? I need a boss to help us get out.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *feeling* (rushed = anxious). Hold the *boundary* (we need to go). Offer a *power choice* to make them a *partner* in the rush, not a *victim* of it.
avoid_step2: Don't offer a choice that takes time. 'Door Boss' (opening/closing) is quick.
phrase_3: You are such a good helper. Let's take one deep breath *together*, and then 'go' on turbo. You can do this.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *co-regulation* and *partnership*. You are joining *them* in the feeling ('I hate this too').
avoid_step3: Don't expect them to move instantly. They need a second to 'gear-shift' from 'anxious' to 'helper'.
neurological_tip: Intense children are highly sensitive to their parent's emotional state. If you are stressed, their nervous system 'short-circuits'. By naming your own stress ('I'm rushing you'), you validate them and 'clear' the neurological air.
what_to_expect_1: You can prevent 90% of this by *you* getting ready 10 minutes earlier.
what_to_expect_2: They feel seen, not blamed.
what_to_expect_3: They may actually move faster when they feel like a 'partner'.

title: Difficulty with 'Surprise'
wrong_way: Surprise! We're going to the store! ... Why are you crying? It's fun!
phrase_1: I know, I didn't tell you we were going to the store, and now your brain is saying 'Wait! That wasn't the plan!'. You feel caught off guard.
say_it_like_this_step1: Stop what you're doing. Get down. Give them a minute. Validate the *surprise* as a *shock*.
avoid_step1: Don't say 'You need to learn to be flexible'. Don't drag them. Don't shame them for 'ruining the surprise'.
phrase_2: You're right, I should have told you. My mistake. AND we *do* need to go to the store. Do you need a minute to 'adjust your brain'? Or do you want me to tell you the 'secret plan' for the store?
say_it_like_this_step2: Apologize (this is huge). Hold the *boundary*. Offer a *processing choice*. 'Adjust your brain' (giving them 60 seconds) or 'secret plan' (giving them information, which is calming).
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'you can stay home'.
phrase_3: You are very good at knowing what your brain needs. When you're ready, let me know. I'll wait for 60 seconds.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *self-awareness* and *self-advocacy*. You are giving them *time* and *information*, the two antidotes to transition anxiety.
avoid_step3: Don't be impatient during the '60 seconds'. Slowly count in your head.
neurological_tip: Intense (HSC) children process information deeply. A sudden transition interrupts this processing and feels like a neurological 'alarm'. Giving them time and info allows their prefrontal cortex to 'catch up' and turn off the amygdala's alarm.
what_to_expect_1: They will visibly relax when they feel you're no longer 'pulling' them.
what_to_expect_2: This is a massive trust-builder.
what_to_expect_3: In the future, *always* 'preview' for them.

title: Entering Noisy Place (Store/Party)
wrong_way: Come on, stop hiding behind me! Go play! There's nothing to be scared of!
phrase_1: Wow, it's very loud in here. So many lights and sounds. It's a lot for your ears and eyes right now.
say_it_like_this_step1: (Do this *before* you go in, if possible). Get down. Speak low. If already inside, find a quiet corner for a minute.
avoid_step1: Don't force them to 'socialize'. Don't shame them. Don't call them 'shy'.
phrase_2: It's a lot of noise, AND we are here for a little while. Do you need a 'sensory tool'? Do you want to wear your 'superhero headphones' (noise-cancelers) or hold my 'calm-down-charm' (a smooth fidget stone)?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *sensory overwhelm*. Hold the *boundary* (we are here). Offer *sensory tools*.
avoid_step2: Don't let them 'escape' (go to the car), but *do* let them 'regulate' on-site.
phrase_3: You are in charge of protecting your ears/eyes. You can stay here in this 'safe corner' with me until your body feels ready. You let me know.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *sensory self-regulation*. You are giving them the *agency* to decide *when* their body is ready, which paradoxically helps them feel ready faster.
avoid_step3: Don't rush them. They may stay in the 'safe corner' for 10 minutes. That's okay.
neurological_tip: HSCs have more reactive nervous systems. What's 'fun' to you is 'painful' to them. The 'safe corner' and 'sensory tools' are not 'coddling'; they are necessary neurological accommodations, like glasses.
what_to_expect_1: They may choose to stay in the corner the whole time. That is still a success.
what_to_expect_2: They learn they can trust you to protect their sensory needs.
what_to_expect_3: Tantrums-Sensory Meltdown|Social-Overwhelmed at Playdate

title: Waking Up Overwhelmed
wrong_way: Oh, are we crying already? It's a new day! Stop being so grumpy!
phrase_1: Good morning. You woke up and you're feeling so... 'bleh'. Your body still feels tired and the day feels 'too big'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Keep the lights low. Use a very soft voice. Sit on the bed and just rub their back for a minute. Don't talk.
avoid_step1: Don't be 'super-cheerful'. Don't rip open the curtains. Don't start barking orders.
phrase_2: It's hard to wake up. It feels unfair, AND the day is starting. We need a 'soft start'. Do you want 5 minutes of 'cuddle time' before we get up, or do you want me to sing your 'soft good morning' song?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *overwhelm* (waking is a hard sensory transition). Offer a *soft transition choice*.
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'staying in bed'. The boundary is 'day is starting'.
phrase_3: You are in charge of how your body wakes up. Let's wake it up slowly. You let me know when you're ready for the next step.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *transition regulation*. You are giving them control over the *pace* of the morning, which is what their intense nervous system needs.
avoid_step3: Don't rush the '5 minutes of cuddle time'. Set *your* alarm 5 minutes earlier to *allow* for this.
neurological_tip: An intense child's nervous system takes longer to 'boot up'. Abrupt lights and sounds are a 'shock'. A soft sensory 'on-ramp' is not a luxury, it's a necessity for a successful day.
what_to_expect_1: This 5-minute connection in the morning can set the tone for the entire day.
what_to_expect_2: They will feel safe and connected, instead of rushed and anxious.
what_to_expect_3: Morning_Routines-Too Rushed/Frantic|Bedtime-Over-Tired Meltdown

title: Clothing Sensitivities (Tags, Seams)
wrong_way: It's just socks! Stop complaining! Put them on, we are late!
phrase_1: I know. That 'bump' in the sock is bothering you. It feels like all your brain can think about. It's so irritating!
say_it_like_this_step1: Stop. Take the sock off. Validate 100%. Touch the seam and say 'Ugh, this guy? I see him. That looks so annoying.'
avoid_step1: Don't say 'I don't feel anything'. Don't say 'You're overreacting'. Don't force it. This is a real neurological issue.
phrase_2: It's so frustrating, AND we need to wear clothes. We have two minutes to solve this. Do you want to try turning the socks 'inside out' so the seam is on the outside, or do you want to try these 'magic seamless socks'?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *sensory irritation*. Hold the *boundary* (we need clothes). Offer *sensory solutions* as a choice.
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'no socks' (unless that's an option, e.g., with sandals).
phrase_3: You are in charge of making your body comfortable. You're the boss of your body. Let's be detectives and find a solution.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *sensory advocacy*. You are teaching them how to *solve* the sensory problem, not just *react* to it.
avoid_step3: Don't get frustrated if the first solution doesn't work. 'Okay, 'inside out' didn't work. Let's try the next thing.'
neurological_tip: This is a real sensory processing difference (SPD). Their brain's 'Salience Network' is flagging the seam as a 'threat'. Validating this calms the threat response and lets the prefrontal cortex solve the problem.
what_to_expect_1: You may need to cut all tags out of shirts and buy seamless socks. This is a real solution.
what_to_expect_2: They learn that their (sensory) feelings are real and valid.
what_to_expect_3: They feel deeply understood.

title: Too Rushed/Frantic
wrong_way: I already told you! Put your shoes on! We have to go! Why are you crying?
phrase_1: I know! I'm rushing and talking loud, and it's making your body feel all 'shaky' inside. You hate this rushed feeling.
say_it_like_this_step1: STOP. Breathe. Get down to their level. Talk 50% slower and 50% quieter. 'I'm sorry. I'm rushing. Let's take a deep breath *together*.'
avoid_step1: Don't blame them for your stress. Don't say 'You're making me late!'.
phrase_2: I feel rushed too, AND we *do* need to get out the door. Let's do this as a team. You be the 'Quiet Boss' and I'll be the 'Breathing Boss'. Let's do the next 3 steps in silence and calm.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *feeling* (shaky/rushed). Hold the *boundary* (we need to go). Offer a *co-regulation choice*. You are joining them.
avoid_step2: Don't offer a 'race' (that's more stress). The goal is to *lower* the energy.
phrase_3: You are so good at being calm. Let's show each other how calm and fast we can be. Are you ready?
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *co-regulation*. You are modeling calm and inviting them to join you, rather than demanding it.
avoid_step3: Don't start rushing and yelling again. You *must* stay calm and quiet.
neurological_tip: Intense children are emotional 'barometers'. They absorb your stress. Their mirror-neuron system is 'on fire'. The only way to calm them is to calm *yourself* first.
what_to_expect_1: This will, paradoxically, get you out the door faster.
what_to_expect_2: They learn that calm is something you *do together*.
what_to_expect_3: They will feel safe, not 'dragged along' by your anxiety.

title: Refusing Breakfast (Emotional)
wrong_way: You have to eat! You'll be hungry at school! Just eat the toast!
phrase_1: Good morning. You're looking at your food and your stomach feels 'closed'. Sometimes in the morning, we just feel 'not-hungry'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Sit with them for a minute. No pressure. Just observe. 'Is your tummy still asleep?'
avoid_step1: Don't force. Don't threaten. Don't say 'You'll be starving' (this sounds like a threat).
phrase_2: I understand. My tummy feels like that sometimes, too. AND your body *does* need a little fuel. Do you think your tummy could accept something *small* and *easy*? Would you rather 'drink' your breakfast (a smoothie) or have a 'piece' (half a toast)?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *interoceptive feeling* (closed stomach). Hold the *boundary* (need fuel). Offer *low-pressure, sensory choices*.
avoid_step2: Don't offer sugary cereal as a 'bribe'.
phrase_3: You are in charge of your body. What do you think it can 'accept' right now? Even one bite is a good start.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *body-listening*. You're teaching them that 'anxiety' (which often causes 'closed stomach') is a real feeling, and you can work *with* it.
avoid_step3: Don't make a big deal if they only take one bite. 'Good job trying.'
neurological_tip: Morning anxiety is common in intense children and manifests in the stomach (gut-brain axis). Forcing food increases cortisol. A gentle, low-pressure approach ('drinking' breakfast) bypasses the 'fight-or-flight' response and gets fuel in.
what_to_expect_1: They may just not be 'breakfast people'. A smoothie is 100% breakfast.
what_to_expect_2: They learn to trust their body's signals and work *with* them.
what_to_expect_3: Mealtime-Picky Eating (Emotional)|Bedtime-Separation Anxiety at Bedtime

title: Sensory Meltdown (Not a Tantrum)
wrong_way: Stop it! This is enough! You're out of control! Go to your room!
phrase_1: (Say nothing at first). (Your job is safety and calm).
say_it_like_this_step1: Approach slowly, calmly. Reduce all stimuli: lower lights, turn off music. Say as little as possible.
avoid_step1: Don't try to 'reason'. Don't ask questions. Don't grab (unless for safety). Don't punish (this is neurological, not behavioral). Don't say 'Calm down'.
phrase_2: (When there is a tiny pause in crying, whisper): 'I'm right here. You are safe. It's too much noise.' (Repeat).
say_it_like_this_step2: Use a very low, monotone voice. This is not a conversation. It's just 'narrating safety'.
avoid_step2: Don't try to 'fix' whatever caused it. The 'trigger' is gone; this is a neurological 'flood'.
phrase_3: (As they start to come out of it, 10-15 mins later): 'You're coming back. You're safe. Do you want some cold water, or a tight hug?'
say_it_like_this_step3: Offer a *regulation choice* (cold water = sensory; tight hug = proprioception).
avoid_step3: Don't say 'Are you done?'. Don't act like 'everything is normal' immediately.
neurological_tip: A sensory meltdown is a neurological 'storm'. The brain is 'short-circuiting'. They are not in control. Your calm presence and reduction of stimuli are the only things that help their nervous system 're-boot'.
what_to_expect_1: This is exhausting. They will be exhausted after. Plan for 'quiet time'.
what_to_expect_2: This is not 'bad behavior'. This is a nervous system overload.
what_to_expect_3: They learn that even at their 'worst', you are there and they are safe.

title: Disappointment Meltdown (Small Trigger)
wrong_way: You're crying over the RED cup? Are you kidding me? You get the blue cup. Stop crying!
phrase_1: You wanted the red cup so, so much. And you got the blue one. And that just feels like the *last straw*. You are so sad and disappointed, your whole day feels ruined.
say_it_like_this_step1: Get down. Use a 100% empathy voice. The cup is *not* the issue; it's the 'trigger' for accumulated emotion.
avoid_step1: Don't say 'It's just a cup'. Don't say 'You're overreacting'. Don't run to wash the red cup (this teaches that a meltdown 'works').
phrase_2: Your heart is broken about this cup. I get it. It's a huge feeling. AND the red cup is dirty. The blue cup is here. I am going to sit with you while you're sad about this.
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *emotion* (heartbroken) 100%. Hold the *boundary* (blue cup) 100%. And *co-regulate* (I will sit with you).
avoid_step2: Don't say 'but'. Don't try to 'distract' immediately.
phrase_3: It's so hard when things don't go the way we want. You can be as sad as you need to be. When you are ready, your water will be here in the blue cup.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *resilience*. You are giving them *permission* to feel disappointment. You are not 'fixing' the problem; you are supporting them *through* the feeling.
avoid_step3: Don't rush their sadness. Let them cry for a minute.
neurological_tip: Intense children 'stack' small stresses all day. The 'red cup' is just what makes the 'stack' fall over. The meltdown is about the *stack*, not the cup. Validating the feeling helps 'clear the stack'.
what_to_expect_1: They will cry for 2-5 minutes and then, often, will just pick up the blue cup and move on.
what_to_expect_2: They learn that they can survive disappointment.
what_to_expect_3: Tantrums-Fatigue-Induced Meltdown|Screens-Meltdown After Turn-Off

title: Fatigue-Induced Meltdown (End of Day)
wrong_way: Stop it! You're just tired! Why are you fighting me on everything?
phrase_1: You are exhausted. Your body is 'done' and everything feels hard. You're sleepy, hungry, and frustrated.
say_it_like_this_step1: Stop 'everything'. Abandon the 'agenda' (finish dinner, bath). The goal has changed: just 'calm' and 'bed'. Pick them up if you can. Move to a calm, dim location.
avoid_step1: Don't try to 'finish the routine'. Don't scold them. Don't get angry (though it's hard).
phrase_2: I know. You're 'done'. AND I've got you. Let's just 'be'. Do you want me to rock you (vestibular) or give you a 'sandwich hug' (proprioception)?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *exhaustion*. Shift to *sensory co-regulation*. The 'agenda' is gone. The choice is *sensory*. ('Sandwich hug' = squeezing them between two pillows).
avoid_step2: Don't try to 'talk' or 'reason'. Use 90% fewer words.
phrase_3: (Just rock and hum). 'I've got you. You're safe. Shhh.'
say_it_like_this_step3: This is empowerment through *surrender*. You are empowering them to 'shut down' and let your nervous system regulate theirs.
avoid_step3: Don't worry about brushed teeth or pajamas (seriously). Sleep is more important than hygiene *tonight*.
neurological_tip: Their brain is 'fried'. The prefrontal cortex is offline. The amygdala is in charge. Rhythmic sensory input (rocking, patting) and deep pressure (hug) are the only things that can calm the brainstem.
what_to_expect_1: This is 'downstairs brain' territory. You have to go there to get them.
what_to_expect_2: Sleep will happen much faster if you abandon the 'fight' and just 'be'.
what_to_expect_3: Bedtime-Over-Tired Meltdown|Tantrums-Sensory Meltdown

title: Empathy Tantrum (Another Child Cries)
wrong_way: Stop crying! *He* fell, not you! You're fine!
phrase_1: Wow. You heard your friend cry and that made *you* feel so, so sad and scared. You have such a kind heart.
say_it_like_this_step1: Step away from the main 'chaos'. Go to a quiet corner with *your* child. Hug them.
avoid_step1: Don't shame them. Don't call them 'dramatic'. Don't force them to 'keep playing'.
phrase_2: You felt your friend's 'big feeling'. That's called empathy. AND that's a huge feeling to hold. Let's take a deep breath *together* to calm your heart.
say_it_like_this_step2: Name the *skill* (Empathy). Validate it as *huge*. Offer *co-regulation* (breathing).
avoid_step2: Don't say 'He's fine now, so you can stop'. Their feeling is real, even if the trigger is over.
phrase_3: Your heart is so big! AND now your job is to calm *your* body. Do you want a tight hug or a sip of cold water?
say_it_like_this_step3: Empower them by praising their *skill* (empathy), then giving them a *regulation choice* to manage that skill.
avoid_step3: Don't make them feel like 'being empathetic' is 'bad' or 'a problem'.
neurological_tip: Intense (HSC) children have hyper-active mirror neurons. They literally *feel* others' pain. This is neurologically overwhelming. Your job is to teach them how to *manage* this 'superpower', not turn it off.
what_to_expect_1: They learn that their empathy is a gift, not a curse.
what_to_expect_2: They will calm down quickly once they feel 'seen' and safe.
what_to_expect_3: Social-Physical Empathy|Social-Overwhelmed at Playdate

title: Overwhelmed at Playdate (Hiding)
wrong_way: Stop being shy! Go play! You wanted to come here!
phrase_1: I see you. You're here and it's loud, and you want to play, but your body is saying 'Wait, this is too much'.
say_it_like_this_step1: Don't drag them. Get down. Sit on the floor *with them* in the 'corner'. Don't force the interaction.
avoid_step1: Don't call them 'shy'. Don't shame them. Don't 'hand them off' to the other parent/child.
phrase_2: It's a lot of energy, AND I'm right here with you. Do you want to just 'watch' for 5 minutes? Or do you want me to help you get *one* toy and bring it here (to the safe corner)?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *overwhelm*. Offer *low-pressure choices*. 'Watching' (passive observation) is a legitimate first step.
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'Do you want to go home?'. This teaches 'escape'.
phrase_3: You are in charge of when your body is ready. There is no rush. You can 'warm up your engine' slowly. I'll stay here with you.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *self-regulation*. You are giving them *permission* to transition at their *own* pace. This is the opposite of 'pushing them in the pool'.
avoid_step3: Don't look bored or annoyed. Get a book and 'watch' with them.
neurological_tip: An intense child's nervous system needs time to 'scan' and 'process' the environment before it can feel safe enough to 'join'. Forcing them bypasses this neurological need and causes a meltdown.
what_to_expect_1: They *will* join. But it might take 20 minutes.
what_to_expect_2: They learn that you are their 'safe base'.
what_to_expect_3: Transitions-Entering Noisy Place|Social-Losing a Game

title: Losing a Game
wrong_way: It's just a game! Don't be a 'sore loser'!
phrase_1: I know. You tried so hard, and you lost. That is so frustrating! You feel angry and disappointed.
say_it_like_this_step1: Validate the feeling *immediately*. It's not 'just a game' *to them*. The feeling is real.
avoid_step1: Don't say 'You can't win 'em all'. Don't say 'Stop being a baby'. Don't force a 'good game' handshake *while* they're upset.
phrase_2: It's an awful feeling! It's okay to be angry you lost. AND you played the game. Do you want to 'stomp' that anger out (stomp feet), or do you want to 'crush' it in your hands (squeeze a pillow)?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *anger*. Separate it from the *behavior*. Offer a *physical regulation choice*. ('Crushing' the anger is a physical release).
avoid_step2: Don't make them 'play again' right away.
phrase_3: You are a good player. And good players get angry sometimes. What matters is how we help our body calm down *after*. You're learning how to do that.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *resilience*. You are saying the *anger* is normal, it's the *recovery* that's the skill.
avoid_step3: Don't let them 'blame' others. 'Yep, you lost. AND that's frustrating.'
neurological_tip: Intense children have intense feelings. Losing feels like an existential 'failure'. By validating the feeling but focusing on the *recovery*, you teach them to 'lose well', which is a critical life skill.
what_to_expect_1: They might 'crush' the pillow hard. 'Good job. Feel better?'
what_to_expect_2: They learn that 'losing' is not 'dangerous'.
what_to_expect_3: Tantrums-Disappointment Meltdown|Social-Overwhelmed at Playdate

title: Physical Empathy (Child A falls, Child B cries)
wrong_way: Stop crying! You're not the one who got hurt! You're fine!
phrase_1: Wow. When you saw [Friend] fall, you felt his 'ow' in *your* body. That was a big scare for both of you.
say_it_like_this_step1: Validate *their* experience as real. Hug *your* child. Your first responsibility is *your* kid.
avoid_step1: Don't shame them. Don't ignore them to run to the other kid (unless it's a true emergency).
phrase_2: You have such a connected heart. AND [Friend] is being taken care of (by his parent). Let's calm *our* heart now. Do you want to take a breath with me, or do you want a tight hug?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *skill* (connected heart). State the *reality* (other is being cared for). Offer *co-regulation* (breath/hug).
avoid_step2: Don't say 'See, he's fine, so you can stop crying'.
phrase_3: You are so good at feeling things. AND you are also good at calming down. Let's help your body feel safe again.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers the *regulation* of their skill (empathy).
avoid_step3: Don't make them feel like 'feeling too much' is a problem.
neurological_tip: This is a classic Highly Sensitive Child (HSC) trait. Their mirror neurons are so strong they 'catch' others' feelings. They need to be taught how to 'ground' themselves *after* they feel.
what_to_expect_1: They will calm in 60 seconds with validation.
what_to_expect_2: They learn their empathy is a superpower that needs a little practice.
what_to_expect_3: Tantrums-Empathy Tantrum

title: Hitting from Overwhelm
wrong_way: We don't hit! Stop it! That is so mean!
phrase_1: Your body got so 'full' of feelings (noise/frustration) that it 'spilled' and hit. You felt out of control.
say_it_like_this_step1: Remove child from situation *immediately*. 'Let's take a break.' Carry them if you must. Stay calm.
avoid_step1: Don't yell. Don't hit back. Don't shame ('You are mean'). Don't give a punitive 'time out'.
phrase_2: You are having huge feelings, AND it is not okay to hit. Your feelings are okay, hitting is not. Do you want a 'bear hug' (deep pressure) to calm your body, or do you want to 'push the wall'?
say_it_like_this_step2: Separate the *feeling* (ok) from the *action* (not ok). Offer *sensory choices* to *replace* the hitting action.
avoid_step2: Don't focus on 'saying sorry' *yet*. Regulation comes first.
phrase_3: You are learning to control this powerful body. Let's use 'wall pushes' to get that 'spill' energy out.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *sensory self-regulation*. You are giving them a *safe replacement action*.
avoid_step3: Don't make them 'talk about it' yet. The thinking brain is offline.
neurological_tip: This is not 'mean' aggression; it's a sensory/emotional short-circuit. The limbic system overwhelmed the brainstem (fight/flight), and the prefrontal cortex couldn't stop it. Proprioceptive input (hug/push) calms the brainstem.
what_to_expect_1: *After* (maybe 20 mins later) everyone is calm, you can 'repair' (say sorry to the other kid).
what_to_expect_2: They learn they can 'spill' and *still* be helped to recover.
what_to_expect_3: Tantrums-Sensory Meltdown|Screens-Overstimulated by Screen

title: Bath Water Too Hot/Cold
wrong_way: It's not too hot! I checked! Stop being difficult and get in.
phrase_1: Oops! You put your foot in and the water doesn't feel 'just right' to your body. It feels 'too hot' (or 'too cold') *to you*.
say_it_like_this_step1: Pull them out. Validate 100%. *Even if* it feels 'perfect' to you. Their feeling is their reality.
avoid_step1: Don't force them in. Don't say 'It's fine'. Don't laugh.
phrase_2: The water feeling is important, AND we need to get clean. Do you want to be the 'Water Boss'? You can help me add more 'cold' (or 'hot') and tell me when it's 'perfect'?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *sensation*. Hold the *boundary* (bath is happening). Offer *total control* over the solution (they become the 'Water Boss').
avoid_step2: Don't just 'fix it' for them. Give them the cup to add cold water, or let them feel the tap.
phrase_3: You're the boss. Your body knows the perfect temperature. You tell me when it's ready.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *sensory autonomy* and *interoceptive trust*. You are telling them 'I trust what your body is telling me'.
avoid_step3: Don't rush them. Let them add 3-4 'cups' of cold water until they 'feel' they've made a difference.
neurological_tip: Intense children have a narrower sensory 'bandwidth'. What's 'warm' to you can be 'scalding' or 'freezing' to them. Respecting this is critical.
what_to_expect_1: They will feel so powerful being the 'Water Boss' that they will get in willingly.
what_to_expect_2: They learn their sensory needs are valid and respected.
what_to_expect_3: Hygiene-Clothing Sensitivities|Mealtime-Sensory Aversion (Texture)

title: Hates Hair Brushing (Pain)
wrong_way: Stop screaming! It's just a brush! If you don't stop, I'm cutting your hair off!
phrase_1: I know. I know it hurts. You hate this feeling. It feels like 'pulling' on your brain. It's awful.
say_it_like_this_step1: STOP brushing. Put the brush down. Give them a hug. Validate the *pain*. It is 100% real to them.
avoid_step1: Don't say 'You're overreacting'. Don't threaten (to cut hair). Don't 'just get it over with'. Don't hold them down.
phrase_2: I know it hurts, AND we *have* to get the 'tangles' out. We need a *better* plan. Do you want *me* to brush *very slowly*, one tangle at a time, or do you want to be the 'Brush Boss' and do it yourself?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *pain*. Hold the *boundary* (tangles must go). Offer *control* (you do it slowly) or *total autonomy* (they do it). (Use detangler spray and a 'Tangle Teezer'/'Wet Brush' - tools are crucial).
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'not brushing'.
phrase_3: You are in charge of your body. You can tell me 'stop' at any time. Let's be a team. You hold the mirror and tell me where the next 'tangle' is.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *partnership* and *agency*. They become an *active participant* in the 'tangle surgery', rather than a *victim* of the brush.
avoid_step3: Don't lie and say 'it won't hurt'. Say 'I will try my absolute best to be gentle'.
neurological_tip: The scalp is one of the most sensitive areas. Children with SPD feel this pain in an amplified way. Validating the pain is the *only* way. Brute force creates trauma.
what_to_expect_1: This will take twice as long. It will be worth it.
what_to_expect_2: Buy the detangler spray and the right brush. This is 80% of the battle.
what_to_expect_3: They learn you will protect them, even during 'painful' tasks.

title: Toothpaste 'Too Spicy'
wrong_way: It's not spicy, it's 'minty'! It's good for you! Just brush!
phrase_1: Oops! You put that in your mouth and the flavor is 'too big'! It's too 'spicy' (or 'strong') for your tongue.
say_it_like_this_step1: Let them spit. Give them water. Validate the *sensation*.
avoid_step1: Don't force them to keep going. Don't say 'It's not a big deal'.
phrase_2: That flavor is 'too much' for you, AND we have to clean the 'sugar bugs'. Do you want to try this 'no flavor' toothpaste, or do you want to try brushing *first* with just 'water' and then we do a quick 'fluoride' swish?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *sensory* feeling. Hold the *boundary* (we must clean). Offer *sensory choices*. (Buy unflavored or mild strawberry paste).
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'not brushing'.
phrase_3: You are in charge of what goes in your mouth. You pick the 'flavor' (or 'no flavor') that works for you.
say_it_like_this_step3:
This empowers *sensory autonomy*. You are respecting their 'supertaster'
palate.
avoid_step3: Don't worry about the 'brand'. Just find one they will accept.
neurological_tip: Intense (HSC) children can be 'supertasters', with more taste buds. Mint can be physically *painful* to them, like a hot pepper. This is biology, not 'pickiness'.
what_to_expect_1: They will be relieved that you 'believe' them.
what_to_expect_2: Unflavored (like Tanner's) or mild fruit toothpaste is a game-changer.
what_to_expect_3: Mealtime-Sensory Aversion (Texture)|Hygiene-Bath Water Too Hot/Cold

title: Hates Nail Clipping
wrong_way: Stop moving! It's just a clipper! You're going to make me cut you!
phrase_1: I know! You hate this! It looks like I'm 'cutting your fingers off'. It's a scary sound and a scary feeling.
say_it_like_this_step1: Stop. Put the clipper *down* (out of sight). Just hug them. Validate the *fear*.
avoid_step1: Don't hold them down (this is traumatic). Don't threaten. Don't say 'It doesn't hurt'.
phrase_2: It's an awful feeling for you, AND long nails can scratch. We need a *different* plan. Do you want us to 'paint' the nails with the 'magic file' (an electric/soft nail file) or do you want me to try and clip *one* nail while you watch your 'most favorite' video?
say_it_like_this_step2: Validate the *fear* 100%. Hold the *boundary* (nails need care). Offer *alternative tool* choices or *high-powered distraction*.
avoid_step2: Don't offer 'let's do it later'. This just builds anticipatory anxiety.
phrase_3: You are in charge. You tell me which plan feels 'less scary'. We are a team on this.
say_it_like_this_step3: This empowers *partnership* and *harm reduction*. You are joining them to 'fight' the scary task.
avoid_step3: Try *after* a bath (soft nails) or *while they sleep* (last resort).
neurological_tip: The 'click' of the clipper and the sensation can be genuinely terrifying to a child with intense sensory processing. A 'file' (electric file) is quiet and has no 'click'. It's a superior tool for sensory kids.
what_to_expect_1: The 'video' (high distraction) may be the only way. This is about 'task survival', not 'screen time'.
what_to_expect_2: They learn you will help them get through scary things.
what_to_expect_3: Hygiene-Hates Hair Brushing|Bedtime-Nighttime Fears
